note.p: Selection of the Source Text. This edition contains all five of the letters in the Ohio State University Rare Books and Manuscripts Library's (RBMS) collection of Sophia Peabody Hawthorne's letters. We did not seek to include further correspondence between Sophia Hawthorne and Elizabeth Palmer Peabody because of the focus of the project—highlighting RBMS collections and providing students with an editing project manageable in the space of an academic term.

projectDesc.p: "My Dear Elizabeth: Letters from Sophia Peabody Hawthorne to Elizabeth Palmer Peabody, 1837-1868" is an electronic edition of five letters written by Sophia Peabody Hawthorne (1809-1871) to her sister Elizabeth Palmer Peabody (1804-1894). The edition belongs to a series of collaboratively produced electronic editions of previously unpublished nineteenth-century American manuscripts held in the Rare Books and Manuscripts Library (RBMS) at The Ohio State University Libraries. Other editions include "Selected Entries from the Lucius Clark Smith Diaries, 30 July 1862 to 31 December 1862"; "My Dear Elizabeth," five letters written by Sophia Peabody Hawthorne to her sister Elizabeth Palmer Peabody between ca. 1837 and 1868; "Journal of a Tour to Europe," by Samuel Sullivan Cox; and Louisa A. Doane's "Journal of Two Ocean Voyages (1852-1853)."

Each text was initially edited in connection with an undergraduate or graduate course on electronic textual editing offered by H. Lewis Ulman, Associate Professor of English at The Ohio State University. The courses provided students with an opportunity to explore issues of textuality and mediation that arise when our cultural archives spread from page to screen and from library shelves to networked databases. Electronic textual editing served as each class's context for examining what happens—and envisioning what might happen—when artifacts in one medium are represented in another medium, especially with regard to the interpretive work of reading. Electronic textual editions also provided a contact zone that helped students reflect on what manuscript, print, and "born digital" artifacts can tell us about their unique properties and their relationships to one another.

While the students' work focused on providing reliable textual editions, they also explored four threads inextricably woven into the work of electronic textual editing: the lives and historical milieu evoked by the texts; the history, characteristics, and preservation of physical and digital texts; the editorial processes and decisions that shape particular interpretations and presentations texts; and the mediation of electronic delivery systems.

These conceptual focuses, along with the time constraints of academic terms and the need to train students who had, typically, no prior experience in textual editing or the various technologies employed in electronic textual editing, strongly influenced the selection of texts in this series. Working with curators in the RBMS, Professor Ulman identified previously unpublished manuscript materials that were of potentially broad interest and that reflected a curatorial focus of the RBMS collection—for example, letters and personal diaries that connect private lives with larger historical contexts. Focusing on unique manuscript materials not, in all but one case, associated with other copies or later published versions also eliminated the need to compare multiple copies or states of the same work, perhaps held in other archives, an impractical task in the course of an academic term. Other practical matters also informed the choice of materials, including the possibility of scanning the source documents before the class so that students could work with both the original documents and high-resolutions facsimiles as they transcribed and encoded the source texts.

Thus, the editions in this series are documentary editions—interpretations and representations of single documents—designed to provide wider exposure and access to manuscript materials that might otherwise be overlooked, and to provide users with a variety of tools for studying those texts.

While providing a reliable textual edition is a sine qua non, the Stephens edition also explores ways of telling four stories inextricably woven into our work: the lives and historical milieu evoked by the texts, the history of the physical documents, the editorial process that gave rise to this particular interpretation of the texts, and the mediation of our electronic delivery system.

Over the course of several years following the classes in which students worked on the editions, Professor Ulman revised the introductory materials to ensure stylistic consistency and proofed the transcription and encoding. He also redesigned the structure of the editions to meet the requirements of Ohio State's institutional repository, evolving accessibility standards, and feedback from peer reviewers. However, he did not undertake a complete retranscription of the source text or revision of the students' introductory essays and annotations.

editorialDecl.p: Scanning. The manuscript pages were scanned as 24-bit TIFF images at 400 dots per inch (dpi), then coverted to 8-bit JPEG images at 400 dpi and full quality. All edges were overscanned by at least 1/4 inch. No color correction was used at any stage of image preparation, but a scan of a photographer's 18% grey card on the same scanner produced RGB values at the center of 91/95/107 after applying a 150% Gaussian Blur in Adobe Photoshop to average color values. Thus, a properly configured monitor should provide a reasonable approximation of colors on the manuscript pages..

Transcription. Editing of the Hawthorne letters emphasizes diplomatic transcription: abbreviations, recoverable cancelations, punctuation, spelling, underlining, additions above and below the line or in the margins, capitalization, line breaks, and page breaks have all been transcribed and encoded as they appear in the original manuscripts. The representation of those features varies depending on the view of the letter. An explanation of the presentation in each view of the letters can be read via the "About this View" link at the top of each view's page.

Markup and Annotation. XML encoding of the Hawthorne letters follows The Text Encoding Initiative's (TEI) P5: Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange, as customized for the project using the TEI's ODD ("One Document Does it All") process. This editorial introduction and the three "views" of the letters were generated from the main XML file using XSL transformations to produce HTML Web pages. Several of the appendices were encoded in HTML separately. A more detailed description of the markup can be found via the "Appendices" menu, and all source files (XML, XSL, CSS, ODD, RNC) can be viewed and downloaded via the "Source Files" menu.

Introductory material (such as this editorial introduction) as well as annotated lists of people, places, and organizations mentioned in the letters are encoded in the TEI header of the main XML document. Other explanatory annotations are linked directly from the text. Separate appendices provide further information about the project (e.g., acknowledgements, editors' bios, and so on). All these ancillary materials can be viewed via the menus at the top of each page.

Proofing. Students who created the original transcriptions proofread their own transcription and encoding. In preparation for peer review by NINES and preservation in The Ohio State University's Knowledge Bank, the transcriptions and encoding were once again proofread by Professor Ulman.
Peer Review. Anonymous reviewers for NINES provided peer-reviews for the editions, in response to which they were revised and then reviewed by NINES editors before being listed in the NINES database.

Production and Archival Location of Digital Assets. All of the files associated with this edition are accessed via, and archived in, The Ohio State University's institutional repository, the Knowledge Bank.

refsDecl.p: The TEI elements for the individual letters that constitute this edition of Sophia Hawthorne's letters are provided with xml:id values that reflect the letters' dates of composition, using the following naming convention: SPH_YYYYMMDD. Dates of composition were determined from various sources of evidence: the datelines inscribed in the letters, internal evidence in the body of the letters, and perpetual calendars.

The value of @facs elements related to each image that accompanies this edition consist of the filename of the corresponding page image and a "view" designation for pages on which text is written in two or more orientations.

titleStmt.title: Letter from Sophia Peabody Hawthorne to Her Sister, Elizabeth Palmer Peabody, 8 August 1837
titleStmt.author: Hawthorne, Sophia Peabody

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: In this letter, Sophia Peabody attempts to correct misunderstandings between herself and her sister Elizabeth regarding Sophia's estimation of Abigail May Alcott [Mrs. Bronson Alcott] and, more generally, the sisters' differing attitudes toward "fault-finding." Before mailing the letter to Elizabeth, Sophia gives it to her sister Mary, who adds her own perspective on the misunderstanding, asking for sympathy and peace as well as communicating her frustrations with both of her sisters.

physDesc.p: ALS. 4 pp. Cross-writing in two hands. Discussion of postal system.

div.p:
I have just read your long letter.
I cannot wait a moment before disabusing you
of one entirely mistake, which is your impres‐
sion of my estimation of Mrs. Alcott. You never
heard me express for her a want of respect or
love; for from the beginning & through all
I have thought her a sort of sublime phe‐
nomenon — a terrible power made up of
divinest tenderness— vast humanity — infinite
self sacrifice — a perfect juggernaut devotion
to the Right. I have loved her dearly always.
How can you think otherwise. Don't you remember
at theat time my sympathy with her — & afterwards
my writing often to her, & ever since the affectionate
way in which we have ever met. I have always
felt the utmost tenderness for her. I scarcely
ever saw a person who seemed to me so full
of pathos — amounting to the fearful. I am at a
loss to imagine how you have such an idea in
your mind. Does it not show what complete,
misunderstandings may exist — I never thought her deformed, never moved by earthly passion.

I had a long talk with Mary the other
evening about this discussing of people's faults.
She said she never before understood what
I meant, & she did not believe you did.
It is not that I do not see people do wrong — & that
therefore I necessarily am unjust — but I have
understood Christ to teach that if each one looked
only to his own errors, perhaps there would be justermore just
judgment & greater improvement in individuals.
When he speaks plainly I prefer to understand
him plainly, for I find it the most fruitful
of good. It has not been a personal feeling
for particular persons — for Mr. Alcott for instance,
but this general principle, which would make
me feel the same if a person I never knew
were analysed & decided upon. I know
that GOD only can know a person truly,
from my own experience, & I know that immense
mistakes are made in sweeping or even in what
seem cool, rational judgments of others.
But as the seeing mind cannot but observe
I have thought that each person had better
not by talking emphasize bad opinions of men — arguing
pronouncing & deciding upon their motives & actions,
which ever must be somewhat in the dark —
but let the opinion be constantly modified
or changed in the mind by the evolving of circumstances &
the influx of more light. Then no one would
be so cruelly wronged as some are — & there
would be more time & room for the interchange
of thought about things which are eternal —
Christ might say Woe unto you, hypocrites! because
there was no mote in his eye to take out,See Matt. 7: 3-5. & he
could see without clear vision, what was in
man, but it is not so with the less exalted.
I have said to myself Oh let me enjoy & speak
of the good I see — & be silent of the evil I see.
You have & Mary have thought me morbid about
hearing certain people spoken of — I always knew
this was not the truth. It was not the person
but the thing that I struggled against.
Even when I have mutely listened, I have
always had a mental reservation that perhaps
it was not so — for GOD alone could see the heart —
& comprehend all the grounds upon which it
acted. I can see good in being openeyed
& not acting with a rash confidence — but I
suspect I shall live forever & not see good
in dwelling upon personal faults. For my life
I cannot percieveperceive the least use in talking
about them. I never hear of a great crime
committed that I do not wish I had a hundred
thousand arms & powers to guard the person
from being utterly condemned, because no oneman
can know the tragedy, the struggle, the woe,
the misery of the being's inward life who
transgressed—and it is an infinite comfort to me
always to know that GOD knows all & will accordingly
award with infinite tenderness— & allow for all
want of light. A murder which horrifies the
community never seems to me so dreadful or wrong
in the eye of Heaven as the animadversions of
those who think they are more righteous than the
murderer. Nevertheless, I can scertainly suppose
that to you it may seem quite otherwise about
this matter, & that you do your duty in a way
of proceeding, which with my idea—it would
manifestly be wrong for me to adopt.
I never thought it want of charity in you
or Mary to talk of
percieveperceive failings—but that it did
more harm than good to talk about them—
because I know it is impossible for an intelligent
mind not to take observations. But to
it has been productive of more good to
this reflect as little as possible upon the shadow,
but & I & live & expand in the light & &I feel
more love & charity & see more every day.
GOD will give the increase to both our sowings
wayssince both are followed sown in obedience
to the conscience. I never considered myself
better than you or Mary or whoever — but in
some things I am very different in my habits
of mind. I never compare myself with others — I
try to be as simply as possible without thinking
how I am— & I never feel how I am except when I
fall short as I often do of the mark. I am conscious
of it & feel remorse. It is only in remorse that
I feel myself — when I am unjust to others — or
impatient — then I am smitten as with a rod — &
feel how much better others are then I — but the
contrary never occupies my thoughts. I am
If I have verged to either extreme it has been that
every body was better then I, ceteris paribus.
Do not suppose I extend this to fault finding face
to face. I think this is good & productive of great
benefit — for then the two persons being all that
are concerned in the matter can take care of
themselves, & be improved by each other's lights.
It is bad But to talk & judge of a person
who is not present to have his or her dictum
wimay cause great harm & wrong. But do not
ever take for granted by inference a harsh judgment. Now both
you & Mary have taken up this idea of my view of Mrs. Alcott
because I had said she was violent & said tremendous things to
her husband. But you should have stopped at my words — & then you
would
have been
more just —
I never
said I
did not
respect
& love her —
nor implied
it intention‐
ally — I
think we
always
come
nearest
right when
we infer
the best
instead
of the
worst
thing —
I wish
you would
not think
you know
what I
never express.
As to
Beauty
I would
never sacrifice one iota of goodness or truth to it as you might suppose —
but Christ was ever beautiful — & my aim is to do so, as well as true &
good — for I think Beauty is the result of the two. But I never was
aware of seeking beauty in the first place. By keeping my heart
right, whichwh is goodness, I hope to see truth, & then Beauty
will flow. This is my order — not the contrary. I have scarcely
taken the first step; but I feel that this is
the way to go.
You say it is not my tas think of Mr. Alcott's failings — this I did not say
but it is my taste talk of any body's failings. Don't you see why I do not
like to say anything. You misunderstand me
almost always — or give it with
your mind a little different
aspect. That saying ^ you repeat about the
imagination is ^not just as I meant it
but no matter. I hate
to explain.

postscript.p:
Sophy has given me this to read
and send, & I hope it is the
last document ^ of the sort that will pas
She wrote it with difficulty
for she had a raging headache
& has been on the bed & dizzy.
When she finished yrou letter she
burst into tears. I told her I
hoped that would give her
pleasure — she said it did,
but she could not help crying —
& that you did not understand
her about Mrs. Alcott & c. ‐(what
she has said to you here) I told
her I felt as if all was settled
now, & I think she does
but I did not persist in
talking, for she said she felt
as if her body was just where
it was seven months ago tho'
her mind was in a different
state. Now don't tell her I
told you this about her body, for*
*if you wish to have her tranquil, you must let her alone
now. I believe if you & she have any more cryings
about each other I shall die. I have often wished you 1st page
both dead, & I shall never enjoy you
till I think this matter is not to be
alluded to again. I hope you will not
say Alcott for one year if you can help
it, for the word is the touchstone to
all this emotion. There is no temper
in her crying now if there ever was—it
is pure ^ physical agony — but she only apprehends now
that it will be perhaps difficult to appear
natural, at least for a time & that you
will misconstrue that—I have assured
her that you will allow for that, and now
the rest must be left to you. My happiness waits upon
your good judgment. yrou M.
I'm going to send for Harriet & Mrs
Abbot to come & spend a day & night
Monday or Tuesday —
M

titleStmt.title: Letter from Sophia Peabody Hawthorne to Elizabeth Palmer Peabody, 11 November 1839
titleStmt.author: Hawthorne, Sophia Peabody

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: Sophia describes events surrounding her brother George's last illness, including a visit from Rev. Edward Thomson Taylor.

opener.note: The year was added in pencil by an unknown hand.

div.p:
I suppose that Mr Taylor has
told you of George's perfect frame
of mind — of his experience of
that divine glow which was so
unaccountable — but so sweet &
refreshing to him — & seemed so like
an intimation from GOD that
it was well with him —; but he
would not tell you how like
a tender & strong angel he ^ himself was
to us all — what a wonderful
prayer he offered — which seemed
to bring the host of heaven
down to watch & duly ward -
which brought heaven into
George's chamber & carried us
all as on Dove's wings into
the spiritual world. It was the
most fervid — the most affectionate,
tender & divine uplifting of
soul to the infinite Father —
that I ever heard. He prayed for
each — for the Mother, the tender
Mother — who hung around her life
for the Father's manly heart —
for the sister whose duty called
her away — & oh — bless our dear Mary
he said — let not that peaceful
stream be disturbed — he prayed
for the sister present — 'she with
the delicate nerves —' For Aunt
Pickman too he petitioned
Heaven — The tears were at
last loosened from my brain
which I had kept back so long
that I began to feel as if they
were accumulating there —
& they flowed down my face
like a summer rain without
convulsion. After he rose
from his knees, George stretched
out his arms & Mr Taylor
clasped him to his heart in
a long, long embrace — Every
moment ejaculating "The Lord
bless you! Bless you! Bless you!"
in such a thrilling tone that
it seemed as if blessings must
come in legions at the call —
George's thin white hands were
so firmly fastened round his neck
that I thought he would never
let the Angel go — even after he
had blessed him — but at last
he relaxed his hold. Then Mr
Taylor turned to me & took both
hands. Be strong said he. It is
very pleasant on the other side—Be
quiet alike a May morning.
He came with me into my room.
Oh George is a perfect lamb! A
perfect lamb. He is moonlight —
so clear — mild — I would not but
have seen him for the world. It
was worth coming just to look at
him. He never looked so handsome
in his life. There is no distortion
there. All is right. All is right.
I cannot tell you all he said now.
Oh he is the most helpful — the
divinest spirit — is he not?
George said there could not be such
a prayer conceived of. Mr. Taylor
is no sham — he said.
George is very much revived this
afternoon. He had not a bad
chill this morning — hardly any — &
yesterday it was
two hours long
Mary came today & staid two hours
I carried her your letter this afternoon
& she had receivedrecieved no harm.
George thinks it would not be
right for you to come on
Wednesday. He thinks of
every thing in all relations
with exactest precision.
Yesterday he wandered a
little several times, & this
afternoon while I was rubbing
his arm, he was saying
something — & then said something
I did not hear. What did
you say I asked. It believe
was nothing to the purpose, he
replied. I was wandering.
I never saw such clearness. He
looks from some high place
even upon his aberrations.
I can write no more now
I receivedrecieved a blessed refreshment
yesterday P.M. beside Mr
Taylor, a long — closely written letter

titleStmt.title: Letter from Sophia Peabody Hawthorne to Elizabeth Palmer Peabody, January 8th, 1859
titleStmt.author: Hawthorne, Sophia Peabody

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: Sophia and family are in Rome recovering from sickness. The family plans to stay in Rome for February, March, and half of April. From there the famly will travel to Venice, northern Italian cities, Geneva, and Paris. Sophia informs Elizabeth on the status of her friends in Italy.

opener.note: "Mrs H" was added in pencil by an unknown hand.

div.p:
too tired to write a letter,
but cannot bear to let a
chance slip. Una has
written a sad letter which
I fear will make your
heart ache. I am glad
to say that the Roman
fever seems to have been
arrested in her — for she
has had no chills for two
days. She is a lily now,
her lifelong roses snatched
away, but during these
two days I have thought
to see a dawn of roses
in her cheeks and lips,
though she is now suffering
from influenza.

Ada's fever is past. She
is well of that today, but has
a very painful shoulder —
and lies in bed still.
I have had no moment to
write to you in all these
weeks — having been ill
myself in the interval
of nursing others. No Rome
this winter for us so far.
My journal is left in the
middle of a sentence, which
can never be recalled
now, though and I am
sorry, because I had an
idea of the Faun at that
moment.

Perhaps we shall have
February and March
for a little enjoyment
of Rome, and half of April.
Then we leave it for aye
and go to Venice and thence
to the cities in the north
of Italy & to Geneva and
Paris.

Mrs. Ward is here and I
have not had a moment
to go and see her. But I had
a long note from her. She
is very happy and content in her
sunny sky-parlor in the Hotel
d'Angliterre — with no cares, no
anxieties, only hopes she says.
She suffered terribly from the
severe treatment of Dr Simpson
but expects to feel benefit
next summer from it.
Neither have I been able to see
once Mrs Browning, and
only once Mr Browning who
has been three times to see
us. Mrs Browning does not
make visits. Mary Motley
I see here sometimes. I
have read the Dutch RepublicNote about The Dutch Republic..
during my watches, and the
book is superb, I think.
Miss Cushman has been here,
but I could not see her.
Mr. Hawthorne saw her.
No society for me this winter.
Rosebud is exquisitely good
generous and considerate in
these times, but I can give
you no Altar of Roses now.
Mr. Hawthorne is quite
well. Here is cause for
great joy — for last winter he
had the Grippe three months.
Julian also is well with
only slight nose cold.
Rose has today gone to
the Palazzo Galitzin A fashionable district in the 19th century located in the center of Rome, just off the Tiber in Via della Scrofia #117 ROM 208-209. to see
the Westons, who delight in
her. She draws with a
wonderful expression.
Julian copies Flaxman
à merveille.

I long to answer all
your letters one by one —
and I long to tell you much.
I have sent some letters
of Una to you and Mary
lately. I never got
yours and Mary's letters
directed to Florence. Though
Mr Browning has written
about ?them to the Post Office
they do not come. I have
lost all your account of dear
Dr. Wesselhoeft. I endure
astonishingly through all
things. Goodbye with
thousand blessings.

titleStmt.title: Letter from Sophia Peabody Hawthorne to Her Sister, Elizabeth Palmer Peabody, 1863
titleStmt.author: Hawthorne, Sophia Peabody

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: Sophia writes about the economic hardships the family is going through, Rose's current (and Una's past) development through adolescence, and a quarrel with her sister, Mary, about some books.

div.opener:
Sunday
My dear Elizabeth— I have
div.p:
become so occupied with
the unhappy Weiss, that
with my necessary household
cares, mending & making —
I have not had one
moment to answer your
note. It is Sunday and
all the children are at
Church, and I have a
few moments of my own —
and out of a hundred
things I want to do, I
take some time for you.
We could not take
advantage of the free
lessons of Dr. Kinner
for Una, on account
partly andof the expense
of railroad fare — while
there were other reasons
less imperative. I
am very sorry, but
since there is not
literally money enough
for it — I accept the
disappointment. For it
is certainly a very plain
duty not to spend other
peoples' money for
accomplishments — ^or any thing else. And as
we are very closely pressed
this year — and feel it
important not to grind
Julian too closely in
college, (though he must
be exceedingly economical
at the best) — we must
all sacrifice a great
many pleasant things.
✓This penciled check mark was added by an unknown hand. If Mr Hawthorne did
not write, we could by
no means make our
expenses come within
our income, and
it is a pain to him
to be so hard driven
in his present unenergetic
condition, and he
doubts if we can at any rate
easily make the ends
meet. The Smiths have
sent for Una and Julian
to go to see them this
winter. But for the
same reason, they cannot
go. It would cost at
least thirty dollars for
travel from our
door to theirs, and
Julian would have to
have a new suit of
clothes — costing thirty
more — before he could
go. As to me, I am
going without any
thing new whatever
and I only wish I could
give up any thing more
so as to gratify
them. As to their father
he is a perfect Diogenes
or a god — about going
without things. He will
not allow himself the
smallest expenditure.
Julian has had expensive
books stolen by some
thievestheives among the
Sophomores — one very
immense Greek Lexicon,
what I should think
must have cost five
dollars at least.
Professor Gurney says this
is one of the dirtiest
of their dirty tricks, and
that there is no redress.
Julian gets along
splendidly as a brave
and gentle Dear Sir"Dear Sir" is written, upside-down, in the center of this page in what appears to be Nathaniel Hathorne's hand, though the sample is too small too identify with certainty. and stalwart
knight. A gentleman
told me he was looked
upon as a powerful
lion — and one of his
anames is the Immortal
Hawthorne. He makes no
2d
aggression, but
defends the weak—
and no one dares to
touch him — as they
all know him strong —
and find him valiant.
He has not a particle
of low, unchristian vindic -
tiveness in his nature —
They make broad
lanes for him to pass
when they think he
might revenge some
classmate's wrong —
and treat him personally
with high respect and
the good, gentlemanly
Sophomores are his
friends. But if I tell
you so much, you will
say I am making a
fine story and praising
him too much. It is a
pity I cannot talk to
a sister without that
suspicion — is n't it?
When I do not answer
your notes, dear Elizabeth
sometimes, it is not
because I accept
them, but because I
disagree, and think it
of no use to discuss
the matter. Some things
in that long ago note
I agreed with, however —
Rose's face expresses too
much critical displeasure
I very well see often.
She is in precisely the
mood that Una was
in at her age in Rock
Ferry. Una was then
disgusted with every body
and thing that did not
suit her taste & principles
and seemed to fail
utterly in St Paul's
Charity. I was quite
alarmed, until a certain
Mrs. Allbut told me
that I need not fear
at all, for that when
Una was eighteen she
would be all right, and
that this fastidiousness
at her age was the
most hopeful of all
states. I find it true.
Una is always excusing
every body now, and
finding good points
in every one, and no
soul is more full of
generous, self sacrificing
love. Every person I
know in Concord
bursts out to me about
her in enthusiastic
praise — not moderate
but enthusiastic praise.
You get all your evil
impressionsimpressons of her
from the Alcotts probably,
as no one else maligns
her. Mrs Emerson, all
the Emersons, the
Pritchards, the MacKays,
the Hoars, the all
the world of Concord
agree in love to her.
They call her loveliest
the most devoted the
most generous and
all sorts of pretty names.
Miss Rose deserves your
censure, but as she
has a world of adoring
love in her, I hope she
will soonlove all
her fellow creatures
as she now loves
some of them. I
talk with her a great —
deal about the propriety
of feeling genial and
pleased in society —
and I shall continue to
3d
adjure her. But
I do not doubt she
will be a loving and
gracious person. For
you do not know what
a power of generosity
she has — and all in
the true Christian— spirit
of not letting the right
hand know &c. For
this is one thing they
were born with as
I have brought out —
to make no show of
any thing they can
do or feel . . . They are
genuine & and all
as true as heaven itself.
Oh dear — now I am
off on this eulogistic
track. But really if
you lived with them
you would not love
them little. And if
you could see how Julian's
innocence is becoming
virtue, you would be
glad as I am; and
overflow sometimes.
Religious principle is
the only sure guard
angelic, and I am sure
they all have it. They
are all reverent.
I think a cultivated
imagination and a
delicate — or unsmothered
conscience are the diamond
shield against evil.
Julian's memory scintillates
with high, heroic thoughts
and deeds. His father
put into him, reading
aloud, every noble story
of literature. He has
therefore kept the
highest society — and
has no love for
low persons — no
tastes that are ignoble.
But I will stop this
talk — whether or no.
Who told the Queen of
the AngelsPresumably Sophia's sister, Mary Tyler Peabody Mann. that I
complained about the
injury of the books? I
did not — and I never
asked any one to tell
her — I never thought it
owing to her carelessness —
for I know she is
never careless. But
all the fly leaves were
torn out up to the
very commencement
of the text in very
many. It seemed as
if they were torn out
for waste paper.
Somebody did it — but
I never supposed
MargaretPresumably Sophia's sister, Mary Tyler Peabody Mann. allowed
it or knew of it.
She will not be so
angry therefore with
me — who sent her no
reproach nor message
and would have
forbidden anyone to
say a word to her —
she will not punish
me, so innocent, by
never borrowing
another book from me!
And she too, the Queen
of the Angels! Tell
her then to lay off her
crown, for she is not
the Regina angelorum
any longer. I wish
folk would leave me
to do my own fault —
finding — my own duty, in
short — and not try to do it for me
4th
The reason I do not
fancy Mrs Pugh is because
she disenchanted herself
by her artificialness and
an effect of unveritable
ness. At first I went
upon your impression
of her, and your talk of
her to me. But very
soon she became
oppressive and sultry
and not genuine to
me. And I declare I
cannot help this.
It is her fault, not
mine. No reasoning
no developments of
her life will help it.
Every person must stand
or fall upon their character
as evidenced by their
presences. It is a
law of the universe
and no talk will alter it.
I take a fancy to
Mr. & Mrs. Turner, of
whom you speak very
Sneeringly because they
are single, simple, true,
lovely and refined —
These are very good
reasons, and very good
qualities.

I am sorry I have
no drawings for your
babies this week.
But I have been
overwhelmedoverwhemed since
the suicide of Adelaide
Weis with cares
for the rest of them —
I have had to
neglect many things —
not however so imperative
stationer's mark.
as their needs.

I have the comfort of
a perfect peace and
order & intelligence
in the kitchen — for
which I am most
thankful — for I
dreaded Ann's going
to California— away
from me. There are
other treasures, I
find among the
Irish besides her.
Indeed I knew this
but feared not to
become possessed
of them.

I hope you are very
well and that the
Queen of the Angels
is well this autumn.
Give my love to
her.

titleStmt.title: Letter from Sophia Peabody Hawthorne to Elizabeth Palmer Peabody, 4 December 1868
titleStmt.author: Hawthorne, Sophia Peabody

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: This letter, written by Sophia Hawthorne to her sister Elisabeth Peabody, discusses the death of their nephew Horace Mann, Jr. and the subsequent reaction of his mother (their sister, Mary Tyler Peabody Mann).

div.p:
Oh Elisabeth, your letter of NovemberNov 12 came
yesterday noon, after immense longing
on my part to hear from you about
Horace particularly, and now alas the
beloved child has passed into the
heavens. From the delay of the letter,
I had great fears that either Horace
or Mary were very ill, and that you
waited to give me good news. I am
deeply grieved, and notwithstanding
your precaution in preparing the
way to tell me finally that he was
"still forever." I was smitten to the
heart when I came to that; for I
began to think you told me the details
of his illness as the "sad news" and that
he lived yet here below. Fortunately
the blow made me burst into tears
and sobs, (a very rare thing for me now)
so that the acute pang did not hurt me
so much. But I am in the greatest
anxiety about Mary. The world has
lost a rare person. Where will you find
such fidelity, such devotion, such earnestness,
such perseverance, such solemn
dedication of the talents God has given.
I loved him greatly, and my respect
for his life was profound. I mourn
for my dear Horace with deepest
sorrow. I did hope to persuade him
to come to us in Dresden for recreation,
change and observation of the gains
of science here. He was so large in
his scope. When I asked him once
which branch of science he preferred
he looked at me with surprise and replied
"How can I like one branch of science better
than another?" True enough — how can
anyone — and yet, how few have this
broad love, and how many keep in
one groove. His was indeed the genuine
love for the widest knowledge. His
magnificent purposes and hopes
probably needed another sphere to
be fulfilled, for oh Elisabeth, I never
believed that Horace would live to
the prime of manhood in this world.
I was sure he would die young, and
so I am not surprised, however much
I grieve. He had not robustness of
constitution enough to bear such constant
and profound study. He told me once
he was never for one moment rested,
and never expected to be! He worked
with pure spirit always, and not
with physical power. Even his
enormous walks and climbings
and reachings in America and
the Sandwich IslandsThe Hawaiian Islands.. and everywhere,
were accomplished because his
will and wish were so omnipotent—
not because he had bodily force
enough. It was sublime and
beautiful to a degreehardly
surpassed. I feel honored that I
was related to him. I think there
never was a purer sacrifice offered
to disinterested science. He was a
martyr without stain. When I saw
him first with the seal of death on his
brow (as I know) it was astonishing to
observe the fine beauty of his face—
the intellectual dignity suddenly
increased so much. Julian remarked
yesterday that when he bade him
goodbye on the eve before we left Boston
that he had never seen him look
so well—(meaning so fine in expression)
Ah it is we only who are disappointed!
and lamenting— For just think of him
now with no obstruction between him
and the universe of God. Think how
his face shines with eternal joy as
he apprehends the secrets of creation.
If he had had a stronger body and
tougher health, he would doubtless
have lost in delicacy of perception
and acute sensibility to all the
mysterious laws and results of Nature.
Also in living here among less
exalted persons in his vocation he might have
finally merged spirit in the matter
that is also so wonderful and fine.
He was too susceptible of suffering for
those who loved him vitally, to really
enjoy his progress. I was always in
terror of the sudden breaking down
of overtaxed brain and nerves.
I thank God he did not lose his
reason under the pressure of his cares.
Oh how much better that he should
enter into endless Rest than to
merely exist here without use of reason.
That would surely have broken our hearts.
But he entered the mansion prepared
for him in his Heavenly Father's House, living
and conscious through all his being.
Were not the words he first heard
well done, Thou good and faithful servant. Thou hast
been faithful over a few things. I will
make thee ruler over many things!
Enter thou into the joy of thy Lord.Matt. 25:21.
For has not he gained five talents
more than the five which the Lord
delivered unto him?Matt. 25:21. Did he ever
fold one in a napkin? When his
mother's first agony of separation is
over, his noble life will come back
to her like an angel of consolation —;
and she will feel rewarded in a
celestial way for her truly divine
care and sympathy with him. One in
a thousand mothers is she, and it
would indeed be a pity to part such
love. It is not parted— oh non —; His
gratitude on earth to her could never
reach his gratitude to her in heaven
where he can better appreciate it and
understand her single devotion to
his highest good. And his father is
there to receive and welcome him
without a misgiving! For did not he
rise to his father's most ardent
prayers for him? I am comforting
myself —; How I wish I could comfort
Mary. God alone can speak to her.
I do not know what it is to lose a son.
God bless and help her, as He surely will.
Her remarkable fortitude will aid her
now, and also her generous tenderness.
I hope she will live for the others.
She said once she wished to live till
Ben was 21. I hope she will not
be drawn up into the blessed land
after Horace, and I think she will
stay for the rest. She has such
identity of life with her children,
that I cannot conceive of their doing
without her on earth. If Horace could
miss any thing in a state, the felicity
of which eye hath not seen nor
ear heard, it would be his mother's
embracing care. But he has that
still, and all else superadded, and
as I first exclaimed with sobs
and tears He never will be tired any
more! Human power could never
compass what he meant to do, and
not to disappoint him, His Heavenly
Father took him from earthly
obstacles and constant suffering,
where he can never more be cold
nor weary nor interrupted in his
immortal course of knowledge
and aspiration. Two witnesses
have George and Ben now
in heaven —; Two angels to watch and
ward. I trust you have written
again to tell me how they do and
how they bear it. But of Mary
I am most fearful, because she
is frail, and had lately been so ill.
She has such strength of endurance that
I believe she will live here as long
as she desires to live, because also
her wish to live is so unselfish.
She wishes to live for her children
and not for herself. Perhaps by and
by I can write to her, but how could
I speak to her now. I am dumb
before her in this terrible moment.

I think with satisfaction of what
is very trifling to others —; but not to
me. It is that Horace was always
very affectionate and sweet to me
I remember his grasp of hand
and his smile whenever I met
him —-; and whenever he said Aunt
Sophia—; was always moved, each
time, as if he first said it then.
I also remember well what a respect
and regard my husband had for
him. He always liked to talk
with him and to hear everything
he said. His sincerity, seriousness
of purpose and varied knowledge
and intelligence made him
so attractive to Mr. Hawthorne —;
and in his presence there was such
a modest dignity of manners —;
so thoughtful an air of
conscientious consideration as
was truly beautiful.
I believe the last time I saw him
in Concord was when he came in
loaded with lovely arethusas —; and
presented me with a radiant
sheaf of them. I was always thankful
to see him come —; but how seldom
he came. I felt he could not waste
his time, for seldom anyone so
impressed me with the value of
moments. He never wasted any
time! What a marvel! Not since
childhood, when he began to try
chemic experiments. How thoroughly
he obeyed the commandWork while
it is day —;

When he came home from the
Sandwich Islands, there was a knot of
pain on his brow, which did not wear
quite away till I saw the seal of
death take its place. I always
wondered what had troubled him.
Perhaps he has now told his mother —;
but I am sure he had some great
trouble which he thought best to
keep to himself. I sometimes
thought I would ask him to tell
me, as he might be reluctant to
disturb his mother —; for I thought
he would feel better to relieve
himself of it, whatever he was.
It is no matter now —-; for when
the golden gate turned back on its
inges, and shut him in from
the world, all cares were left
outside, and his brow now is smooth
with peace. I begin today to be
conscious of his peace —; I could think
of only Mary's loss and the loss of
us all at first. Today I have written
myself into an ecstasy with his gain
and relief and I wish I could know
soon about Mary. No doubt a letter
is on its way to me now. This one
of yours may have been at Thode's
a few days. Do not send any more
to the Bankers. 46 B Bautzner
Strasse is my address. The Postman
is a nice man, and every thing is safe
with him. I suppose the Bankers
cannot send letters about.

I do not incline to write or think
of any thing but Horace and Mary.
You have received four letters from me
before this time —; the three last were
announcements. I will write again
We are all well, and happy to be here.
I should like some money very much. I
was to have some from Ticknor & Fields
in November for the former booksptr type="noteAnchor" target="notebooks"/>Nathaniel Hawthorne's American Notebooks, published by Ticknor and Fields, that Sophia felt she was not being properly compensated for. GALE 169.—; But I hear
the firm is dissolved. If so, perhaps I
am without redress. I wish Mr Hillard
could send my January dividend so I
can have it by 1st January. What he
is sure of.he can advance me perhaps.
All send love and deep sympathy. We are at
housekeeping since 19th November and taking German lessons. Goodbye

p.add:
Do not write the A in my name, because I write it here Sophia Hawthorne
only. Rose wrote to you last week.
PS. The postage is 10 cents to Dresden
